metadata.title: FedRAMP System Security Plan (SSP)

roles.title: Prepared By
roles.desc: The organization that prepared this SSP. If developed in-house, this is the CSP itself.

roles.title: Prepared For
roles.desc: The organization for which this SSP was prepared. Typically the CSP.

roles.title: System Security Plan Approval
roles.desc: The individual or individuals accountable for the accuracy of this SSP.

roles.title: Information System Owner
roles.desc: The individual within the CSP who is ultimately accountable for everything related to this system.

roles.title: Authorizing Official
roles.desc: The individual or individuals who must grant this system an authorization to operate.

roles.title: Authorizing Official's Point of Contact
roles.desc: The individual representing the authorizing official.

roles.title: Information System Management Point of Contact (POC)
roles.desc: The highest level manager who responsible for system operation on behalf of the System Owner.

roles.title: Information System Technical Point of Contact
roles.desc: The individual or individuals leading the technical operation of the system.

roles.title: General Point of Contact (POC)
roles.desc: A general point of contact for the system, designated by the system owner.

roles.title: System Information System Security Officer (or Equivalent)
roles.desc: The individual accountable for the security posture of the system on behalf of the system owner.

roles.title: Privacy Official's Point of Contact
roles.desc: The individual responsible for the privacy threshold analysis and if necessary the privacy impact assessment.

roles.title: Owner of an inventory item within the system.
Administrative responsibility an inventory item within the system.
ICA POC (Local)
roles.desc: The point of contact for an interconnection on behalf of this system.
roles.remarks: Remove this role if there are no ICAs.

roles.title: ICA POC (Remote)
roles.desc: The point of contact for an interconnection on behalf of this external system to which this system connects.
roles.remarks: Remove this role if there are no ICAs.

roles.title: ICA Signatory (Local)
roles.desc: Responsible for signing an interconnection security agreement on behalf of this system.
roles.remarks: Remove this role if there are no ICAs.

roles.title: ICA Signatory (Remote)
roles.desc: Responsible for signing an interconnection security agreement on behalf of the external system to which this system connects.
roles.remarks: Remove this role if there are no ICAs.

roles.title: Consultant
roles.desc: Any consultants involved with developing or maintaining this content.

roles.title: Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program (FedRAMP) Program Management Office (PMO)
Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program (FedRAMP) Joint Authorization Board (JAB)

locations.title: CSP HQ
locations.remarks: There must be one location identifying the CSP's primary business address, such as the CSP's HQ, or the address of the system owner's primary business location.

locations.title: Primary Data Center
locations.remarks:
There must be one location for each data center.
            	There must be at least two data centers.
            	For a data center, briefly summarize the components at this location.
            	All data centers must have a conformity tag of "data-center".
            	A primary data center must also have a conformity tag of "primary-data-center".

locations.title: Secondary Data Center
locations.remarks:
There must be one location for each data center.
            	There must be at least two data centers.
            	For a data center, briefly summarize the components at this location.
            	All data centers must have a conformity tag of "data-center"
            	An alternate or backup data center must also have a conformity tag of "alternate-data-center".

parties.party-name: Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program: Program Management Office
parties.remarks:
This party entry must be present in a FedRAMP SSP.
            	The uuid may be different; however, the uuid must be associated with the "fedramp-pmo" role in the responsible-party assemblies.

parties.party-name: Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program: Joint Authorization Board
parties.remarks:
This party entry must be present in a FedRAMP SSP.
            	The uuid may be different; however, the uuid must be associated with the "fedramp-jab" role in the responsible-party assemblies.
Generic placeholder for any external organization.
Generic placeholder for an authorizing agency.

metadata.remarks:
This OSCAL-based FedRAMP SSP Template can be used for the FedRAMP Low, Moderate, and
            High baselines.
         	Guidance for OSCAL-based FedRAMP Tailored content has not yet been developed.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
This control is met by CoreOS when SELinux is in Enforcing mode
and configured against the SELinux Targeted policy.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
The customer will be responsible for enforcing a limit on consecutive
failed login attempts.

A control response is planned. Progress can be tracked via:

https://issues.redhat.com/browse/CMP-124

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
The customer will be responsible for taking required
actions defined by the customer, upon account lockout.

A control response is planned. Progress can be tracked via:

https://issues.redhat.com/browse/CMP-124

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
The customer will be responsible for displaying a system use
notification banner to users. A successful control response will need
to address the conditions under which the banner will be displayed
(if a non-government user accesses the system, the system use
notification banner may not be appropriate), as well as the contents
of the notification message.

In context of CoreOS, a banner must be displayed for all means
of accessing CoreOS itself (e.g. service consoles, remote access
through SSH, etc).

A control response to AC-8 is planned. Progress can be tracked
via:

https://issues.redhat.com/browse/CMP-125

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
The customer will be responsible for displaying the use notification
banner until the user acknowledges the usage condition and takes
explicit actions to further access the system. A successful control
response will need to address the means by which the user will indicate
acknowledgement and move forward.

A control response to AC-8 is planned. Progress can be tracked
via:

https://issues.redhat.com/browse/CMP-125

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
The customer will be responsible for displaying a system use
information message to users. A successful control response will need
to address the conditions under which the message will be
displayed (if a non-government user accesses the system, the system
use information message may not be appropriate), as well as the
contents of the notification message, including references to
applicable monitoring, recording, or auditing, and authorized usage
of the system.

A control response to AC-8 is planned. Progress can be tracked
via:

https://issues.redhat.com/browse/CMP-125

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
The customer will be responsible for determining the conditions
under which the system use notification will be displayed. These
conditions must be reviewed and accepted by the FedRAMP JAB.

A control response to AC-8 is planned. Progress can be tracked
via:

https://issues.redhat.com/browse/CMP-125

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
The customer will be responsible for how the system use notification
will be verified and how often it should be re-displayed and
re-verified. These conditions must be reviewed an accepted by the
FedRAMP JAB.

A control response to AC-8 is planned. Progress can be tracked
via:

https://issues.redhat.com/browse/CMP-125

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
The customer will be responsible for verifying that the system use
notification is being displayed as required, either through a
configuration baseline check or via other means. If this verification
does not happen through a configuration baseline check, the JAB must
review and accept the process used to perform the verification.

A control response to AC-8 is planned. Progress can be tracked
via:

https://issues.redhat.com/browse/CMP-125

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Regardless of access mechanism, such as the CoreOS Console or remote
access attempts through SSH, unauthenticated users will only be shown the
system use notifications (as defined in AC-8) and login prompt. This is
non-configurable behavior.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
CoreOS was designed to satisfy the audit requirements outlined
in the Configuration Annex to the Protection Profile for General
Purpose Operating Systems available at
https://www.niap-ccevs.org/Profile/PP.cfm.

Specifically, the minimum auditable events included:

| Configuration Action | CNSSI 1253 Value or DoD-specific Value | NIAP Reference |
| Audit All Logons (Success/Failure) and Logoffs (Successful) | Authentication events: (1) Logons (Success/Failure); (2) Logoffs (Success) | FAU_GEN.1.1.c |
| Audit File and Object Events (Unsuccessful) | File and Objects events: (1) Create (Success/Failure); (2) Access (Success/Failure); (3) Delete (Success/Failure); (4) Modify (Success/Failure); (5) Permission Modification (Success/Failure); (6) Ownership Modification (Success/Failure) | FAU_GEN.1.1.c |
| Audit User and Group Management Events (Success/Failure) | User and Group Management events: (1) User add, delete, modify, disable, enable (Success/Failure); (2) Group/Role add, delete, modify (Success/Failure) | FAU_GEN.1.1.c |
| Audit Privilege or Role Escalation Events (Success/Failure) | Privilege/Role escalation (Success/Failure) | FAU_GEN.1.1.c |
| Audit All Audit and Log Data Accesses (Success/Failure) | Audit and log data access (Success/Failure) | FAU_GEN.1.1.c |
| Audit Cryptographic Verification of Software (Success/Failure) | - | FAU_GEN.1.1.c |
| Audit Program Initiations (Success/Failure) | Application (e.g., Firefox, Internet Explorer, MS Office Suite, etc.) initialization (Success/Failure) | FAU_GEN.1.1.c |
| Audit System Reboot, Restart, and Shutdown Events (Success/Failure) | System reboot, restart and shutdown (Success/Failure) | FAU_GEN.1.1.c |
| Audit Kernel Module Loading and Unloading Events (Success/Failure) | - | FAU_GEN.1.1.c |

Additionally, CoreOS was designed to satisfy the audit requirements
outlined in Intelligence Community Standard Number 500-27, "Collection
and Sharing of Audit Data" (ICS 500-27) that were found to be applicable
to operating systems performing as a container host. A copy of ICS 500-27
can be found at
https://www.dni.gov/files/documents/FOIA/DF-2016-00213.pdf

Selected audit events from ICS 500-27 include:
  * Authentication events
    * Logons (Success/Failure)
    * Logoffs (Success)
  * File & Object Events
    * Create (Success/Failure)
    * Access (Success/Failure)
    * Delete (Success/Failure)
    * Modify (Success/Failure)
    * Permission Modifications (Success/Failure)
    * Ownership Modifications (Success/Failure)
  * User & Group Management events
    * User add, delete, modify, suspend, lock (Success/Failure)
    * Group/Role add, delete, modify (Success/Failure)
  * Use of Privileged/Special Rights events
    * Security or audit policy changes (Success/Failure)
    * Configuration changes (Success/Failure)
  * Admin or root-level access (Success/Failure)
  * Privilege/Role escalation (Success/Failure)
  * Audit and log data accesses (Success/Failure)
  * System Reboot, Restart & Shutdown (Success/Failure)
  * Application (e.g. Netscape, IE, Lotus Notes, etc) initialization
    (Success/Failure)

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Coordinating the security audit function with other
organizational entities is outside the scope of
system configuration.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Red Hat did not express judgement in the rationale for why auditable
events are deemed to be adequate to support after-the-fact
investigations of security incidents.

For rationale regarding why the auditable events are deemed to be
adequate to support after-the-fact investigations of security
incidents, please contact your countries Common Criteria
representative:

https://www.commoncriteriaportal.org/ccra/members/

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Determination of which events are to be audited within CoreOS from
the subset of auditable events defined in AU-2(a) is an organizational
control outside the scope of CoreOS configuration guidance.

Should system operators decide to use the NIST National Checklist for
OpenShift 4.x, all events identified in AU-2(c) are selected to be
audited.

Additionally, in regards to the AU-2(d) requirement of defining
"the frequency" of auditing for each identified event, it should be
noted that the CoreOS audit subsystem generates audit events in
realtime (e.g. immediately upon an audited event occurring).

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
AU-3 is satisfied when the following configuration checks have been
implemented:
   * CCE-82463-1: Enable auditd Service

These configuration checks are enabled in the NIST National Checklist

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
By default, CoreOS auditing uses the internal system clocks to generate
time stamps for audit records. At the code level, this is accomplished
through the use of the C programming language time.h which is part of the
C Standard Library.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
By default, the CoreOS auditing records time stamps for audit records
that can be mapped to Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). For example
in the following node audit record:

type=SYSCALL msg=audit(1364481363.243:24287): arch=c000003e syscall=2 success=no exit=-13 a0=7fffd19c5592 a1=0 a2=7fffd19c4b50 a3=a items=1 ppid=2686 pid=3538 auid=1000 uid=1000 gid=1000 euid=1000 suid=1000 fsuid=1000 egid=1000 sgid=1000 fsgid=1000 tty=pts0 ses=1 comm="cat" exe="/bin/cat" subj=unconfined_u:unconfined_r:unconfined_t:s0-s0:c0.c1023 key="sshd_config"
type=CWD msg=audit(1364481363.243:24287):  cwd="/home/shadowman"
type=PATH msg=audit(1364481363.243:24287): item=0 name="/etc/ssh/sshd_config" inode=409248 dev=fd:00 mode=0100600 ouid=0 ogid=0 rdev=00:00 obj=system_u:object_r:etc_t:s0  nametype=NORMAL cap_fp=none cap_fi=none cap_fe=0 cap_fver=0
type=PROCTITLE msg=audit(1364481363.243:24287) : proctitle=636174002F6574632F7373682F737368645F636F6E666967

The msg field records a time stamp and a unique ID of the record in the form audit(time_stamp:ID).
Multiple records can share the same time stamp and ID if they were generated
as part of the same Audit event. The time stamp is using the Unix time
format - seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on 1 January 1970.

See https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_enterprise_linux/8/html/security_hardening/auditing-the-system_security-hardening
for more example and explanation of auditing.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Configuration management is enforced through Ignition configurations
and Operators.

Ignition is the utility that is used by Red Hat Enterprise Linux CoreOS (RHCOS)
to manipulate disks during initial configuration, confirming all new machines
meet the declared configuration.

Ignition is meant to initialize systems, not change existing systems. After
a machine initializes and the kernel is running from the installed system, the
Machine Config Operator from the OpenShift Container Platform cluster completes
all future machine configuration.

Operators are a method of packaging, deploying, and managing a Kubernetes
application. Watching over the CoreOS environment, using its current
state to make decisions in real time, the Machine Config Operator (MCO)
manages updates and configuration changes to essentially everything between
the kernel and kubelet.

For additional information:
https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/latest/architecture/architecture-rhcos.html#rhcos-about_architecture-rhcos
https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/latest/operators/olm-what-operators-are.html
https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/latest/nodes/nodes/nodes-nodes-managing.html
https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/latest/installing/install_config/installing-customizing.html

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Ensuring that the organization uses software and associated
documentation in accordance with contract agreements and copyright laws
is the complete responsibility of the organization. Red Hat's
responsibilities to assist with the tracking of software licensing and
usage of software provided by Red Hat will be fulfilled in accordance
with all applicable contracts and agreements established for the
project with the organization.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Tracking the use of software and associated documentation protected by
quantity licenses to control copying and distribution is an
organizational control outside the scope of CoreOS.

For CoreOS nodes operating in an OpenShift environment, the OpenShift
Cluster Manager (OCM) service acts as a bridge to Red Hat Subscription Manager.
A cluster connected to the internet can send telemetry to OpenShift Cluster
Manager at https://cloud.redhat.com/openshift/, which then handles
integration with Red Hat Subscription Manager to track subscriptions
for OpenShift clusters.

For disconnected clusters utilizing CoreOS, there is no way to send telemetry data to
OpenShift Cluster Manager. In this case, the organization must manually
register their disconnected clusters with OpenShift Cluster Manager
following the instructions at https://access.redhat.com/solutions/4930131

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Developing an organization-level contingency planning policy is
outside the scope of CoreOS configuration.

To facilitate a control response and assist in contingency planning,
CoreOS nodes should not contain any stateful information as stateful information
should exist only in etcd and get persisted to OCP nodes via operators.
Because of this, CoreOS nodes can be added/removed as necessary to fully
recover/restore the CoreOS environment.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Providing contingency training to information system users consistent
with assigned roles and responsibilities at an organization-defined
frequency is outside the scope of CoreOS configuration.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Testing the contingency plan for the information system at an
organization-defined frequency using organization-defined tests
to determine the effectiveness of the plan and the organizational
readiness to execute the plan is outside the scope of
CoreOS configuration.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Organizational reviews of the contingency plan test results is outside
the scope of CoreOS configuration.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Organizational process to initiate corrective actions, if needed,
are outside the scope of CoreOS configuration.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
The customer will be responsible for conducting daily incremental and
weekly full backups of user-level information contained in the
information system. Additional requirements and guidance include
maintaining at least three backup copies of user-level information (at
least one of which is available online) or provides an equivalent
alternative. A successful control response will detail how backups of
user-level information occurs, and how three backup copies are
maintained.

Conducting backups of user-level information to include the backups of
a centralized identity provider is an organizational control outside the
scope of CoreOS configuration.

CoreOS nodes should not contain any stateful information as stateful information
should exist only in etcd and get persisted to OCP nodes via operators.
Because of this, CoreOS nodes can be added/removed as necessary to fully
recover/restore the CoreOS environment.

To assist System Administrators and organizations in their control response,
documentation about backing up CoreOS user-level information stored in etcd in OpenShift nodes
can be viewed at:

https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/latest/backup_and_restore/backing-up-etcd.html

Node handling such as adding and removing CoreOS nodes can be viewed at:

https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/latest/nodes/nodes/nodes-nodes-working.html

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
The customer will be responsible for conducting daily incremental and
weekly full backups of system-level information contained in the
information system. Additional requirements and guidance include
maintaining at least three backup copies of system-level information (at
least one of which is available online) or provides an equivalent
alternative. A successful control response will detail how backups of
user-level information occurs, and how three backup copies are
maintained.

Conducting backups of system-level information is an organizational
control outside the scope of CoreOS configuration.

CoreOS nodes should not contain any stateful information as stateful information
should exist only in etcd and get persisted to OCP nodes via operators.
Because of this, CoreOS nodes can be added/removed as necessary to fully
recover/restore the CoreOS environment.

To assist System Administrators and organizations in their control response,
documentation about backing up CoreOS system-level information stored in etcd in OpenShift nodes
can be viewed at:

https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/latest/backup_and_restore/disaster_recovery/about-disaster-recovery.html

Node handling such as adding and removing CoreOS nodes can be viewed at:

https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/latest/nodes/nodes/nodes-nodes-working.html

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
The customer will be responsible for conducting daily incremental and
weekly full backups of information system documentation including
security-related documentation.

Conducting backups on information system and security-related documentation
is an organizational control outside the scope of OpenShift configuration.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
The customer will be responsible for protecting the confidentiality,
integrity, and available of backup information at storage locations.
Additional requirements and guidance include determining
what elements of the cloud environment require the Information System
Backup control. The customer will determine how Information System
Backup is going to be verified and appropriate periodicity of the
check.

Protecting the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of backup
information at separate storage locations an organizational control outside the
scope of OpenShift configuration.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
The customer will be responsible for documenting how to reconstitute
their CoreOS environment. A successful control response will detail
processes used to fully recover/restore the CoreOS environment.

CoreOS nodes should not contain any stateful information as stateful information
should exist only in etcd and get persisted to OCP nodes via operators.
Because of this, CoreOS nodes can be added/removed as necessary to fully
recover/restore the CoreOS environment.

To assist System Administrators and organizations in their control response,
documentation about disaster recovery procedures for CoreOS nodes in OpenShift can be
viewed at:

https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/latest/backup_and_restore/disaster_recovery/about-disaster-recovery.html

Node handling such as adding and removing CoreOS nodes can be viewed at:

https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/4.5/nodes/nodes/nodes-nodes-working.html

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:

configuration.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Organizational processes ensuring that, upon termination of individual

organization-defined time period, are outside the scope of

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Organizational processes ensuring that, upon termination of individual

CoreOS configuration.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Organizational processes ensuring that, upon termination of individual
employment, exit interviews are conducted that include a discussion of

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Organizational processes ensuring that, upon termination of individual

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Organizational processes ensuring that, upon termination of individual
employment, the organization retains access to organizational

are outside the scope of CoreOS configuration.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:

employment, the organization notifies organization-defined personnel
or roles within an organization-defined time period, are outside

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Organizational processes to review and confirm ongoing operational

outside the scope of CoreOS configuration.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Organizational processes to initiate organization-defined transfer
or reassignment actions within organization-defined time period
following the formal transfer action are outside the scope of
CoreOS configuration.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Organizational processes to modify access authorizations as needed to
correspond with any changes in oeprational need due to reassignment
or transfer are outside the scope of CoreOS configuration.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Organizational notifications of organization-defined personnel
or roles within an organization-defined time period are outside
the scope of CoreOS configuration.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Organizational process to develop and document access agreements for

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Organizational processes that ensure individuals requiring access to
organizational information and information systems sign and re-sign
access agreements are outside the scope of CoreOS configuration.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Organizational processes that ensure individuals requiring access to
organizational information and information systems sign and re-sign
access agreements are outside the scope of CoreOS configuration.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Organizational processes that ensure individuals requiring access to
organizational information and information systems sign and re-sign
access agreements are outside the scope of CoreOS configuration.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Organizational processes requiring third-party providers to comply

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Organizational processes to document presonnel security requirements

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Organizational processes to require third-party providers to notify
organization-defined personnel or roles of any personnel transfers or
terminations of third-party personnel who possess organizational
credentials and/or badges, or who have information system privileges

scope of CoreOS configuration.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Organizational employment of a formal sanctions process for individuals

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:

or roles within an organization-defined time period when a formal

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Organizational development, documentation, and dissemination to

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Organizational development, documentation, and dissemination to
organization-defined personnel or roles a risk assessment policy
and procedures is outside the scope of CoreOS configuration.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Organizational development, documentation, and dissemination to
organization-defined personnel or roles a risk assessment policy

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Organizational review and updates to the risk assessment policy

CoreOS configuration.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Organizational review and updates to the risk assessment policy
and risk assessment procedures is outside the scope of
CoreOS configuration.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:

CoreOS configuration.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Organizational processes to review risk assessment results at

of CoreOS configuration.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Organizational processes to disseminate risk assessment results to
organization-defined personnel or roles are outside the scope
of CoreOS configuration.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:

organization-defined frequency or whenever there are significant
changes to the information system or environment of operation
(including the identification of new threats and vulnerabilities),
or other conditions that may impact the security state of the system,

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
The customer will be responsible for analyzing their CoreOS deployment for
flaws, reporting on those flaws, and correcting them. A successful
control response will include a discussion of the process by which
flaws are discovered and remediated, as well as tools that are used to
assist in detection and remediation.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
The customer will be responsible for testing CoreOS updates
related to flaw remediation prior to installation. A successful
control response will discuss the testing process (e.g. the
nature of the test environment, the types of testing performed,
the tools in testing, etc.).

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
This control reflects organizational procedures/policies, and is not
applicable to the configuration of CoreOS.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
This control reflects organizational procedures/policies, and is not
applicable to the configuration of CoreOS.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
The customer is responsible for ensuring that they employ malicious
code protection at information system entry, and exit points to detect
and eradicate malicious code. A successful control response will need
to address use of code protection mechanisms to protect assets from
malicious software (i.e. Viruses, malware, rootkits, worms, and
scripts). In regards to CoreOS, this is generally through
the use third party tools.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Updating malicious code protection mechanisms whenever new releases
are available in accordance with organizational configuration
management policy and procedures is an organizational control outside
the scope of CoreOS configuration.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Configuring malicious code protection mechanisms is an organizational control outside
the scope of CoreOS configuration.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Performing periodic scans of the information system per organization-defined frequency
and real-time scans of files from external sources via endpoints or network entry/exit
points as the files are downloaded, opened, or executed in accordance with organizational
security policy is an organizational control outside
the scope of CoreOS configuration.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Blocking malicious code, quarantining malicious code, sending alerts to administrator, or
some other organization-defined action in response to malicious code detection is an organizational control outside
the scope of CoreOS configuration.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Addressing the receipt of false positives during malicious code detection and eradication
and the resulting potential impact on the availability of the information system is an organizational control outside
the scope of CoreOS configuration.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
This control reflects organizational procedures/policies, and is not
applicable to the configuration of CoreOS.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
This control reflects organizational procedures/policies, and is not
applicable to the configuration of CoreOS.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Monitoring the system to detect unauthorized local, network, and remote connections
is an organizational control outside the scope of CoreOS configuration.
Functionality to meet this control can be provided by a third party vendor.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Identifying unauthorized use of the information system through organization-defined
techniques and methods is an organizational control outside the scope
of CoreOS configuration. Functionality to meet this control can be provided by a third party vendor.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Deploying monitoring devices is an organizational control outside the scope of CoreOS configuration.
Functionality to meet this control can be provided by a third party vendor.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Deploying monitoring devices strategically within the information system to collect organization-determined
essential information is an organizational control outside the scope of CoreOS configuration.
Functionality to meet this control can be provided by a third party vendor.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Deploying monitoring devices at ad hoc locations within the system to track specific types of transactions
of interest to the organization is an organizational control outside the scope of CoreOS configuration.
Functionality to meet this control can be provided by a third party vendor.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Protecting information obtained from intrusion-monitoring tools from unauthorized access,
modification, and deletion is an organizational control outside the scope of CoreOS configuration.
Functionality to meet this control can be provided by a third party vendor.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
This control reflects organizational procedures/policies, and is not
applicable to the configuration of CoreOS.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
This control reflects organizational procedures/policies, and is not
applicable to the configuration of CoreOS.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
This control reflects organizational procedures/policies, and is not
applicable to the configuration of CoreOS.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
A control response for SI-5(a) is planned. Engineering progress can be
tracked via:

https://issues.redhat.com/browse/CMP-396

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Receiving information system security alerts, advisories, and directives from
organization-defined external organizations on an ongoing basis is an
organizational procedures/policies outside the scope of CoreOS configuration.

How to configure organization notifications for Red Hat security advisories on Red
Hat specific products can be accomplished following the following documentation:

https://access.redhat.com/security/updates/advisory

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Disseminating security alerts, advisories, and directives to organization-defined
personnel or roles, organization-defined elements within the organization,
organization-defined external organizations are organizational
procedures/policies outside the scope of CoreOS configuration.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
Implementing security directives in accordance with established time frames or notifying
the issuing organization of the degree of noncompliance is an organizational
procedures/policies outside the scope of CoreOS configuration.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
The customer will be responsible for handling and retaining
information within, or hosted by, CoreOS in
accordance with applicable federal laws, Executive Orders,
directives, policies, regulations, standards, and operational
requirements. A successful control response will need to outline
the specific requirements applicable to customer information
handling and retention, and the means by which those requirements
are met.

bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.description: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.
bdba9d56-2be4-498d-8d31-b43cab6a44bd.remarks:
A control response for SI-16 is planned. Engineering progress can be
tracked via:

https://issues.redhat.com/browse/CMP-391
